body.p: The HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 EON (ESX on boarding) Service is an inventory, which interacts with the VMware vCenter server and collects available information from data centers, clusters, datastore, dvSwitch and portgroup details. When a cloud admin wants a particular cluster to be a compute resource in HP Helion Openstack 2.0, Eon provisions nova proxy service VM for each cluster and OVSvApp service VM for each ESX host in that cluster.
The integration of EON with HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 automates the steps for moving/adding a cluster in a compute resource. You must execute a few EON CLI commands to do so.

Moreover, EON is not installed by default. To install EON service, you must uncomment eon-deploy.yml file at ~/helion/hos/ansible/hlm-deploy.yml in the deployer node. For more details, refer to ESX installation.

section.p: EON is installed on the master control plane node and the Eon CLI is installed on the HLM Deployer node which is used by the Cloud Admin to setup vCenter Compute Proxy and OvsvApp nodes.

section.title: EON CLI Operations
section.p:
The EON client CLI package provides an http-client coupled command-line tool for managing EON (ESX management) services.
vCenter Operations
Cluster Operations
Network Operations

VMware vCenter is an appliance that is used to manage multiple ESXi hosts through a single console application. VMware ESXi is a visualization platform on which you create and run virtual machines. VMware vCenter acts as a central administrator for ESXi hosts that are connected on a network. You can pool and manage the resources of multiple ESXi hosts while monitoring and managing your physical and virtual infrastructure.
Register/Add a vCenter
You can add the vCenter using EON python client. You must enter all the arguments to add the vCenter; otherwise you will be prompted to enter them.# eon vcenter-add --name <vCenter Name> --ip-address <vCenter IP address> --username <vCenter Username> --password <vCenter Password> --port <vCenter Port>where:
vCenter Name - the identical name of the vCenter server.
vCenter IP address - the IP address of the vCenter server.
vCenter Username - the admin privilege username for the vCenter.
vCenter Password - the password for the above username.
vCenter Port - the vCenter server port. By default it is 443. Please do not change the port unless you are sure about the vCenter Port.
Sample Output:# eon vcenter-add --name vc01 --ip-address 10.1.200.41 --username administrator@vsphere.local --password password --port 443 +------------+--------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +------------+--------------------------------------+ | created_at | 2015-08-20T12:08:09.000000 | | deleted | False | | deleted_at | None | | id | BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 | | ip_address | 10.1.200.41 | | name | vc01 | | password | <SANITIZED> | | port | 443 | | type | vcenter | | updated_at | 2015-08-20T12:08:09.000000 | | username | administrator@vsphere.local | +------------+--------------------------------------+

ul.li:
Show a vCenter details
Shows the details of the specific vCenter.# eon vcenter-show <vCenter ID>
where:
vCenter ID - the UUID of the vCenter (shown in the output of eon vcenter-list).
Sample output# eon vcenter-show BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 +------------+--------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +------------+--------------------------------------+ | created_at | 2015-08-20T12:08:09.000000 | | datacenters| DC1 | | deleted | False | | deleted_at | None | | id | BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 | | ip_address | 10.1.200.41 | | name | vc01 | | password | <SANITIZED> | | port | 443 | | type | vcenter | | updated_at | 2015-08-20T12:08:09.000000 | | username | administrator@vsphere.local | +------------+--------------------------------------+

Update a vCenter
Updates the registered vCenter’s attribute (like name, username, password, port)# eon vcenter-update --name <vCenter Name> --ip-address <vCenter IP address> --username <vCenter Username> --password <vCenter Password> --port <vCenter Port> <vCenter ID>
Sample output:# eon vcenter-update --name vc02 --ip-address 10.1.200.41 --username administrator@vsphere.local --password password --port 443 BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 +------------+--------------------------------------+ | Property | Value | +------------+--------------------------------------+ | created_at | 2015-08-20T12:08:09.000000 | | deleted | False | | deleted_at | None | | id | BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 | | ip_address | 10.1.200.41 | | name | vc02 | | password | <SANITIZED> | | port | 443 | | type | vcenter | | updated_at | 2015-08-20T12:08:09.000000 | | username | administrator@vsphere.local | +------------+--------------------------------------+

Delete a vCenter
If you have any imported cluster ensure that you have deactivated them and then un-import the cluster(s) before executing the delete command.
Unregisters the specific vCenter. vCenter delete fails, if you have any imported clusters that are activate clusters.# eon vcenter-delete <vCenter ID>
Sample output:# eon vcenter-delete BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674

section.p:
This section lists the cluster operations performed in a vcenter.No two clusters should have the same name across datacenters in a given vCenter.
List clusters in a vCenter
Displays a list of clusters in a specific vCenter.# eon cluster-list --vcenter-id <vCenter ID>
Sample output:
# eon cluster-list --vcenter-id BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 +------------+----------+------------+---------------+ | MOID | Name | Datacenter | Import Status | +------------+----------+------------+---------------+ | domain-c21 | Cluster1 | DC1 | not_imported | +------------+----------+------------+---------------+

ul.li:
Import cluster in a vCenter
Import cluster allows you to import the clusters using EON CLI under the given vCenter. This operation provisions (creates) the plain shell VMs for compute proxy node and Ovsvapp nodes which are configured later in stages through HLM. The cluster state changes from “not_imported” to “imported”when you execute the following command.# eon cluster-import --vcenter-id <vCenter ID> --cluster-name <Cluster Name> --cluster-moid <Cluster Moid>
Where:
vCenter ID - ID of the vcenter containing the cluster.
Cluster Name - the name of the cluster that needs to be imported.
cluster Moid - Moid of the cluster that needs to be imported.
Sample output:# eon cluster-import --vcenter-id BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 --cluster-name Cluster1 --cluster-moid domain-c21 +--------------+-----------+ | Property | Value | +--------------+-----------+ | cpu_free | 83071.73 | | cpu_total | 83072 | | cpu_used | 0.27 | | datacenter | DC1 | | disk_free | 1022.79 | | disk_total | 1023.75 | | errors | [] | | memory_free | 496.82 | | memory_total | 511.76 | | memory_used | 14.94 | | name | Cluster1 | | state | importing | | switches | [] | +--------------+-----------+

Unimport cluster in a vCenter
Unimports the cluster in a specific vCenter. This operation de-provisions (deletes) the compute proxy node and Ovsvapp nodes. The cluster state changes from “imported” to “not_imported” when you execute the following command.# eon cluster-unimport --vcenter-id <vCenter ID> --cluster-moid <Cluster Moid>
Sample output:# eon cluster-unimport --vcenter-id BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 --cluster-moid domain-c21 Cluster domain-c21 unimport initiated

section.p:
This involve getting a sample network information template.
Get network info template
Saves the sample network config. json file to the mentioned file (NETWORK_CONF_FILENAME).# eon get-network-info-template --filename <NETWORK_CONF_FILENAME>
Sample output:# eon get-network-info-template --filename net_conf.json --------------------------------------------------------------- Saved the sample file to net_conf.json ---------------------------------------------------------------

li.p: Creates the required Distributed Virtual Switches and Portgroups as per in the inputted network json file.# eon set-network-info --vcenter-id <vCenter ID> --datacenter-name <datacenter name> --config-json <NETWORK_CONF_FILENAME>

ul.li:
Delete network for a Datacenter
Deletes the Distributed Virtual Switches and Portgroups created for Compute proxy and Ovsvapp nodes.# eon delete-network-info --vcenter-id <vCenter ID> --datacenter-name <datacenter name>
Sample output:# eon delete-network-info --vcenter-id BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674 --datacenter-name DC1 Successfully deleted network info of vCenter: BC9DED4E-1639-481D-B190-2B54A2BF5674

Using EON CLI you can perform the following functions:
Adding a new ESX host to a cluster which is already enabled as a compute resource
Enabling a new cluster as a compute resource
Removing an existing cluster from the compute resource pool
Removing an existing ESX host from cluster
